name: route
description: show / manipulate the IP routing table
usage:
route [-CFvnNee] [-A family |-4|-6]

route  [-v] [-A family |-4|-6] add [-net|-host] target [netmask Nm] [gw Gw] [metric N] [mss M] [window W] [irtt I] [reject] [mod] [dyn] [reinstate] [[dev] If]

route  [-v] [-A family |-4|-6] del [-net|-host] target [gw Gw] [netmask Nm] [metric M] [[dev] If]

route  [-V] [--version] [-h] [--help]

options.description: use the specified address family (eg `inet'). Use route --help for a full list. You can use -6 as an alias for --inet6 and -4 as an alias for -A inet
operate on the kernel's FIB (Forwarding Information Base) routing table. This is the default.
operate on the kernel's routing cache.
show numerical addresses instead of trying to determine symbolic host names. This is useful if you are trying to determine why the route to your nameserver has vanished.
use netstat(8)-format for displaying the routing table. -ee will generate a very long line with all parameters from the routing table.

tldr:
> Use route cmd to set the route table.
> More information: <https://manned.org/route>.

- Display the information of route table:

`route -n`

- Add route rule:

`sudo route add -net {{ip_address}} netmask {{netmask_address}} gw {{gw_address}}`

- Delete route rule:

`sudo route del -net {{ip_address}} netmask {{netmask_address}} dev {{gw_address}}`
